title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
The US Senate has voted to approve Joe Biden's $1.9tn stimulus legislation, taking the president's plan to stoke America's economic recovery a big step closer to its final passage in Congress but sending another jolt through financial markets.

The upper chamber of Congress passed the fiscal stimulus legislation by 50 to 49, following party lines with all Democrats voting in favour and all Republicans present opposing.

The bill is now expected to go to the Democrat-controlled House of Representatives for a final vote on Tuesday and will then head to Biden's desk to be signed into law.

The centrepiece of the stimulus package is a new round of means-tested direct payments worth $1,400 per person for Americans earning less than $75,000 per year, part of a package of measures to help with large-scale fiscal transfers directly targeted at low- and middle-income families.

Also included is an extension of federal emergency unemployment benefits worth $300 per week until early September.

In addition to the financial support for American families there is $350bn in aid to states and local governments, the expansion of a tax credit and extra funding for the rollout of vaccinations and the reopening of schools. An earlier proposal to raise the federal minimum wage from $7.25 to $15 was dropped after the Senate's parliamentarian ruled that it could not be approved by a simple majority in the upper chamber of Congress.

Futures trading suggests US stock markets are in for more falls on Monday following the passage of the stimulus bill through the Senate. Nasdaq 100 futures were down about 2 per cent in European trading, suggesting the tech-focused index could drop further after sliding about 8 per cent over the past three weeks. Selling also continued in the US government bond market. The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury rose 0.04 percentage points to above 1.6 per cent, close to its highest level in a year.

Coronavirus digest

  • More than 4.4m new businesses have been created in the US since last March, according to the Census Bureau, far exceeding the uptick that has occurred during previous recessions. Data out on Friday showed the US economy created 379,000 jobs in February.

  • The Bank of Japan will maintain monetary easing but lay the groundwork for a “nimble” response to changing economic conditions, according to the central bank's deputy governor.

  • Brazil is battling a second virus onslaught, stoked by a more contagious P. 1 strain.

  • The EU will urge the US to permit the export of millions of doses of AstraZeneca's vaccine.

  • More than half of adults in rich countries will still be waiting to receive their first vaccine dose in 15 months' time, the head of a logistics group distributing jabs has warned.

Sanya Ojiambo argues that the post-pandemic recovery is a chance to address gender inequality. Follow our Covid-19 live blog and vaccine tracker.

In the news

‘I just didn't want to be alive any more' Meghan Markle was left suicidal by her experience with a British royal family that refused to protect her from hateful tabloids and fretted about the skin colour of her unborn child, the Duchess of Sussex revealed in a two-hour broadcast on Sunday with Oprah Winfrey. (FT)

Oil price jumps above $70 after attack Oil prices rose above $70 a barrel for the first time in 14 months after Saudi Arabia, the world's top oil exporter, said the energy facilities at one of the largest oil shipping ports on earth had been attacked on Sunday by Iran-backed Houthi forces in Yemen. (FT)

GE nears deal to sell plane leasing unit General Electric is nearing a deal to sell its aircraft leasing business to Irish group AerCap for more than $30bn, said people briefed about the matter. GE Capital Aviation Services is among the world's largest leasing companies, buying aircraft and leasing them to airlines. (FT)

  • Italy's billionaire Agnelli family has continued its expansion into the luxury sector with the acquisition of a stake in French luxury shoe maker Christian Louboutin. 

New York Senate leader calls for Andrew Cuomo to resign Andrea Stewart-Cousins, the Democratic majority leader in the state's Senate, argued that the governor had become a distraction as additional women came forward to accuse him of inappropriate behaviour and called on the three-term New York Ggovernor to step down. (FT)

ECB quizzes banks over exposure to Greensill Supervisors at the European Central Bank have asked the continent's lenders for details of their exposure to stricken Greensill Capital and its client GFG Alliance, as officials try to understand whether the crisis is contained, according to four people familiar with the matter. (FT)

Beijing set to cut proportion of directly elected HK lawmakers Hong Kong's new election law, which will be formally unveiled at the communist party's National People's Congress this week, will reduce the proportion of democratically elected legislators and tighten President Xi Jinping's grip on the territory. (FT)

Pope Francis ends historic visit to Iraq The first ever papal visit to Iraq, including to the former Islamic State stronghold of Mosul, ended on Monday. During the three-day visit the pontiff also held a historic iconic interfaith meeting with the most eminent Shia Muslim cleric Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani. (FT)

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe faces new court case Dominic Raab, Britain's foreign secretary, has called on Iran to end the “cruel and intolerable ordeal” endured by the charity worker as she faced another court case despite being released from house arrest. (FT)

The day ahead

Trial of ex-police officer accused of killing George Floyd begins Jury selection is due to begin today in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd, a 46-year-old black man. The death sparked nationwide protests against racism and police brutality. (FT, Minneapolis Star Tribune)

Policymaker presentations Andrew Bailey, governor of the Bank of England, will address the post-coronavirus economic outlook in a speech at the Resolution Foundation on Monday. The European Central Bank will publish the weekly figures for its pandemic emergency purchase programme. (FT)

Schools in England reopen Almost all English pupils will restart face-to-face lessons as the first part of the UK government's “road map” out of a national lockdown begins. The Office for National Statistics will publish figures about vaccine hesitancy. (FT)

International Women's Day 2021 The theme of this year's celebrations is “choose to challenge”, with events taking place around the world to expose gender bias and inequality. Meet our cast of world-changing women. (IWD, FT)

The latest in our Future of Work series of live events focuses on the workforce. HR leaders and their teams are central to defining business strategy and reshaping their organisations as the crisis evolves from a social disaster to an economic imperative. Register now.

What else we're reading

The race to scale up green hydrogen For decades, hydrogen has been hailed as a potentially revolutionary alternative to fossil fuels but its high costs and complexities have stunted attempts at creating whole new economies. Can the gas help solve the world's dirtiest energy problems? This is the first in a series examining whether hydrogen can help cut emissions across industries.

Why Walmart is betting on banking What, exactly, is Walmart up to? Following news the vast retailer has poached Omer Ismail, the leader of Goldman Sachs' start-up consumer banking business, the question has become more pressing for the banking industry. One thing is almost certain, writes US Financial Editor Robert Armstrong, Walmart is betting that the regulatory environment has changed. (FT)

Rio de Janeiro's deepening crisis Brazil is reeling from overlapping crises. Its economy has barely grown for a decade and that was before the coronavirus pandemic created both a health emergency and a deep recession. Now its most famous city is mired in heavy debt and violent crime. (FT)


Wishful thinking on China will not serve American interests While the former president lacked a coherent strategy for countering the rise of China, and his vitriolic rhetoric didn't help America, the past four years did at least bring an end to the wilful blindness, writes Rana Foroohar. (FT)

Mothers step back at work A global survey of FT readers indicates that two in five working mothers have taken, or are considering taking, a step back at work during Covid-19. Separately, only one in 10 of those appointed as chief executive or executive chair of the world's largest 500 companies in the past two years were women, according to a shareholder advisory company. Read our Special Report series on Women in Business.

  • Another study found that a shortfall of confidence accounts for a third of women's lower levels of financial literacy relative to men. (FT)

Do young people really need the office? Emma Jacobs argues that there is a risk in romanticising a return to the office for young people. It sometimes seems during the pandemic, she writes, that the idea of the workplace has become invested with magical powers. (FT)

Podcast of the day

Disrupting the hospital Could a piece of high-tech cloth keep Covid-19 patients out of hospital and allow them to be monitored at home? In the latest episode of the Tech Tonic podcast, Hannah Kuchler, the FT's pharma and biotech correspondent, reports on the wearable technology changing healthcare during the pandemic and examines what it means for the future of patient care. (FT)
